Comment: Solar and wind as intermittent sources of electricity in the grid need to have back-up alternative sources that are continuously available and able to be turned up and down as needed. Natural gas power sources are able to meet this requirement. Ontario Professional Engineer (OSPE) has published a good explanatory document on this on their website (www. ospe.on.ca)

Solar and wind energy density is very small compared with traditional power sources. The cost of connecting large numbers of low capacity power sources to the grid is very high and explains how Ontario has spent billions on "improving and upgrading the grid" to connect these sources. Solar and wind may be fine for standalone on-site power sources, but make no sense at all to be power sources in the public shared electricity grid.

Comment: I think there is a big difference between purposefully leveraging your home and not being a hurry to pay the mortgage off.  While it is generally prudent to pay off debt in a short a period of time possible - there needs to be a balance with investment opportunities.  The point of the article is simply that when you can invest in low or moderately risked securities and earn a higher return than your interest costs it probably doesn't make sense to aggressively pay down the mortgage.

Whether one choose to invest via an advisor or what they invest in is another matter.  But using the example in the article of bank stocks or other common blue chip stocks it is pretty easy to meet or exceed your interest costs just from the first year dividend.  Add in dividend (and capital growth) and over the life span of your mortgage the spread will increase.

Comment: Reader Xandoli repeats the misconception that "/ Chretien got his father out of a Pakistani prison. /"

Incorrect.  First, like the CIA, Pakistan had secret torture prisons, where individuals were held, who had never been charged with a crime, had never had a fair trial, or even a Kangaroo Court.

Chretien did raise Ahmed Khadr's year of extrajudicial detention in a secret Pakistan torture prison with the Pakistani Prime Minister.  But, I believe him when he said that, contrary to some criticisms, he did not beg for his release.  Rather, he did exactly what he should have done.  He says he talked about the rule of law, and suggested the Pakistanis marshal the evidence they had had justifying Khadr's detention, and lay charges and give Khadr a fair trial, or, if they didn't have enough evidence to justify laying charges, and trying him, they should release him.

That the Pakistanis released him is a sign they had no real evidence, not that Chretien did anything wrong.

Comment: Retired Brits legally in Spain do NOT have their healthcare funded by the Spanish government. They are entitled to the same healthcare benefits as Spanish citizens. UK citizens employed in Spain have healthcare insurance deductions from their pay, as has always happened. Living and working in the system will eventually entitle them to Spanish-funded benefits when they retire.

Spain is desperate not to lose the income from these ex-pats. They would also not be keen to have to absorb Spanish workers expelled from the UK to add to the 20% unemployment rate in Spain.

Spain, Portugal, Italy and Greece are economic basket cases, thanks to the EU/eurozone.

Comment: Coming from a professional actuary (who has a book for sale on the subject) this really is just an inflammatory attack on public servant pensions. Show us the numbers!

Ardent opponents of pensions for public service employees conveniently overlook two key facts. First, the average federal public service pension paid out is just over $25,000 annually.  You can buy an annuity for that income even at today's inflated rates for $450,000.  That's still a good deal, but it's a long way short of the $1.2 million that Vettese pulls out of the air.  Second, that $25k is all the average public servant pensioner gets. Their pensions  are reduced by the amount of the CPP benefits when they reach the age of 65, even though they paid additional amounts for the CPP benefits. 

Instead of whipping up envy about public servants, why does Vettese not instead tell us how more Canadians can have financial security in old age?

"In politics and espionage, deniability refers to the ability of a powerful player or intelligence agency to pass the buck and avoid blowback by secretly arranging for an action to be taken on their behalf by a third party ostensibly unconnected with the major player. Comment: Wow, what a great article (almost)!

As a postmodern philosopher, I can say that Mr. McKnight's article about "truth" in postmodern thought is very accurate- but he isn't telling the whole truth. 

In postmodernism, Truth breaks down into categorizes, or as I like to call them - narratives. For example, you have truth that takes the shape of collective narratives like science, where truth is rooted in things like the periodic table and the laws of physics. This Mr. McKnight forgets to mention. 

What he does, is conflates narratives. He conflates a political narrative with another narrative, individual truth. Today, I will agree with Mr. McKnight that there is no truth in the political narrative. But that is because ideology obscures truth. Four main ideologies and their methodologies socialism, liberalism, conservatism and capitalism prevent a political truth from existing.

As for you who read this, you know that truth exists, because you know what you believe as true.

Comment: Your comment on Red Dog being the worst polluter is basically your typical misleading statement (lie) from the EPA and other environmental outfits.

The claim of "one of the most polluting facilities in the United States" comes from the fact that the EPA considers mine tailings as "pollutants". Red Dog produced a lot of tailings, and they are heavy (pollution numbers are calculated by weight).

Now, tailings can be pretty toxic if not treated properly, so there is some truth to the idea, but in fact they are still just a bunch of rocks.  Certainly not what most people think of when people talk of pollution.

Who knows? But I can TOTALLY envision a hot Cargo leading to 5 extra wins, over our last 66 games.

Comment: Renzetti makes some excellent points.
We need to get the past right if we want to make the present right.
That means knowing history from the point of view of the majority of people who were expendable pawns in the making of it.

  We've been through a similar analysis of history in the Vietnam War era.
The hippies, Yippies and anti-war folks gave the world amazing lessons in the history of the US and Canada as well.

   There's history as told by the elitist few who made history through war, colonization, racism, and disregard for the masses of people; and there's the people's history. Two very different stories.

   Statues are a matter of what parts of history we honour and what parts we regret. By extension, today, we need to know who our friends are and who are adversaries are. Because most people don't seem to have that understanding. We live by lies, myths, and half truths; we honour those who betray us and scapegoat those who tell the truth.

“Sacramental signs,” says Saint Thomas, “represent what they signify by natural resemblance.”19 The same natural resemblance is required for persons as for things: when Christ's role in the Eucharist is to be expressed sacramentally, there would not be this “natural resemblance” which must exist between Christ and his minister if the role of Christ were not taken by a man: in such a case it would be difficult to see in the minister the image of Christ. In other words, the laity is too stupid to see Christ in a woman.

Comment: That we have any sort of minimum wage at all is a somewhat arbitrary intervention to begin with. Should we have no minimum wage? I don't see many people arguing for that, so why would we assume that whatever minimum wage we have now is the precise, perfect tipping point and should remain untouched? The content of this article only confirms what is taught in Economics 101...the labor demand 'curve' is downward sloping. Wages go up, demand for labor goes down. That the relationship is inverse is already understood. The exact slope and shape of the curve across a local economy is not. Maybe higher minimum wage will encourage more dignified, dedicated and effective participation in the work force and offset it's predictable hard cost inflationary and job reduction effects.  We may soon get a better idea as these policies roll out. At least the money is earned vs a guaranteed minimum income for just existing and reproducing.

Comment: Many have asked why did devout, practicing Catholics vote for Trump. First of all, I have never voted for a Democrat in my entire life. Born and raised a Republican and would not vote any differently. Secondly, I was a Jeb Bush supporter, and he lost. Trump was my only candidate. I would never have voted for Clinton. Was not even part of the thinking process.

Now, how do I reconcile that decision with my Catholic faith. I don't because the church is not monolithic. Any of us, whether Republican or Democrat, can twist and turn our partisan politics in any religious direction to justify our vote. I did not vote for Trump because of my faith; I did so because I am a conservative. Hilary was not.

I think that it is disingenuous to assume that good Catholics wear their religion on their sleeves when they vote. They don't. No one takes the faithful citizenship booklet to the voting booth; they hardly read it. Instead, we vote according to how we were raised and how we currently think.

Comment: Take a walk some day in a mature forest, whether boreal or west coast rain forest, and then take a walk in a 20 year old replanted forest. Is there a difference? I'd say yes- and it is massive. Tree spacing for one thing-  20-50 feet in older stands, 6-10 in younger ones. Species diversity is way up in older and large critters find the spaces and the selection of food and shelter much more conducive to surviving while we- humans- just find them much more pleasant. It gets better as it ages, but then it gets whacked again.  I worked in the mineral exploration and tree planting businesses for more than 20 years and walked through all sorts of such ground and have seen it all. You talk about false information - get out and see it for yourselves and then see if you can honestly defend industrial forestry practices. Your story is told through high priced publicity agents, spin doctors and lawyers- is that because it cannot stand on its own? Give your head a shake.

Comment: I own a small corporation. My personal income is salary or dividends, both of which are taxed. Any profit left in the corporation is also taxed, albeit at a lower rate. It is not as if having a corporation is a sneaky, evil plan to avoid paying tax; it is just a business structure.  But  I guess you have to write about something in the business column.

Comment: I stopped in at the local North Pole Safeway and was shocked that the sales tax applied to food intended to be cooked at home.  Five percent on the dollar. I could live with a seasonal sales tax due to the short duration and significant impact from tourists. 

 I do think any sales tax should exclude food and basic necessities such as heating fuel, medications, bathroom tissue and school supplies. And of course Bush Alaska would pay twice the sales tax, perhaps three times, for the same amount of food or necessities as urban Alaskans.

Comment: And then there are those dang details to overlook to try and make your point, right Walt Deal?  The article is about the decline in Alaska's Beaufort Sea, one of the three census areas where the polar bears clearly are declining.  So, of course the bears that show up at Kaktovik are refugees from the declined ice conditions in the Southern Beaufort.  

The fascinating thing to me about our changed and changing climate in Alaska (have you missed that, Walt?) is exactly what the bears at Kaktovic are demonstrating.  They are in the process of adapting to their changed habitat.  Will they learn to forage better on land and survive along the Arctic coast, even if at lower numbers, in spite of decreasing sea ice?  Will they interbreed more with the brown bears in the area?  Fascinating to watch.

Keep up the good work, USGS!

The author bases his article on a number of assumptions that he takes as "given". Those numbers are based, themselves, on a number of assumptions, the foremost of which is repeal only, since the final bill has not been approved and so the final numbers aren't yet available; but, I suspect, regardless of the text of the final bill, "24MM will be left uninsured" will continue to be the mantra of the opposition.

Comment: There are many lessons from the Watergate scandal.  One of the big ones is personified by the Washington Post Executive editor Benjamin Bradlee, who demanded verification and fact-checking every single step of the way.  He didn't get it, of course, but nobody could, the story was still unfolding and there were many unknowns--a lesson lost on many today who point accusing fingers at media and shout "lies!" and "fake news!"  (Imagine the public screaming that at reporters Woodward and Bernstein!)

What Bradlee got--and it served him and the American people well--were direct quotes of key players, including, most tellingly, Attorney General, John Mitchell. When a newspaper or TV journalist reports "so and so said such and such" that's NOT fake news, Chieh-ChungChen.  That's accurate reporting.

Comment: "Then she could have laid the groundwork for productive discourse by alluding to the universally shared values of presuming innocence and proving guilt only through credible evidence, and ended by inviting everyone to pursue improvement in service delivery by re-examining everything short of those basic principles."  Presumption of innocence entails the crown must establish the guilt of the accused,  not the accused her innocence. Basing conclusions on credible evidence is a basic principle of rational inquiry and belief.  Neither principle is universally shared---check out totalitarian regimes in the 20th century where political utility trumped these standards. Nor does either dictate what standard or level of proof or establishment on credible evidence is required. Certainty, beyond a reasonable doubt, or simply probability? Butt's omission of the standard of proof beyond a reasonable doubt for criminal convictions is worrisome.We need to resist tampering with it.

Comment: I have no issues with legal assisted suicide but I do take issue with the idea that hospices or any institutions are obligated to provide this service.    
We have little information on the mental impact to doctors of having to participate in an assisted suicide.  It's estimated that less than 1% of doctors would do this work.  While I'm sure some of this 1% are compassionate, I personally would find it creepy to know that such a doctor actually enjoyed his/ her job.   I don't think anyone should be asked to do this as part of their job duties.  It should be voluntary and if it's voluntary it will be difficult to always have such a doctor available on short notice.
What the government is obligated to do is provide a solution for those who seek this service.  I would suggest that a pharmaceutical one with the required checks and balances is an obvious low cost answer.  As to the assistant, the one wanting to end his/ her life should have to find that person.  That's their responsibility

Comment: Well, they can review all they want.  I can almost guarantee you that other than the exercise of having them reviewed, very little will change.  I am willing to bet that the majority of the 'contentious' files will involve two things;   alcohol and consent.  These circumstances are not conducive to a successful prosecution, especially if it is 'she said, he said' situation.  Morning after remorse is not adequate grounds for a charge of sexual assault. 
In BC, it is Crown Counsel who has the charge approval, and unless there is a 'likelihood of conviction,' they will not approve charges, even if the police do forward them.  

 What the authors are missing, in their headlong rush to change the rules, is the fact that the courts do not treat cases such as this sympathetically. Poor cases make poor case law, and make it harder to get convictions in the deserving cases.

Comment: The distinction between "clerical" and "lay" is artificial; it has no theological basis and truly no basis in reality.  The defensive insistence on labels to perpetuate the distinction between "clergy" and "laity" is silly at best, and divisive at worst.  As St. Paul wrote to the Galatians: "There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free person, there is not male and female, there is not clergy or lay; for you are all one in Christ Jesus."
OK: Paul didn't write "there is not clergy or lay".  He didn't have to; the distinction hadn't been drawn yet. It's time for us to grow up and abandon the silly nonsense we use to divide, control and limit each other.
This issue would not arise if the Ministry of Acolyte, which is not a clerical ministry, were open to women; but in yet another sign of the fear that characterizes so much of the church's discipline, the formal ministries of Acolyte and Lector are reserved to men -- which is indefensible.

Comment: This is pretty much the inevitable result of government trying to "force" demand to be want it wants: Demand doesn't change but supply and price do.

A LOT of people simply WANT to live in a detached home, and no matter what government policy is put in place people are still going to want that.   So if government puts in place rules that make building detached homes difficult all it will do is dry up supply and raise prices.

The real take-away here: The *EXACT SAME THING* is going to happen with the newly announced rent control.  People who want apartments are still going to want apartments, but by trying to force down rent all that will happen is new supply will dry up and developers will build something else.  Lower supply means one thing and one thing only: higher prices.

This is just one of many cases where government intervention has the exact opposite effect of what the government WANTS their action to accomplish.

Comment: Overall, this was a good article, but I have to disagree with the author that income sprinkling is somehow justified.  It is not, simple as that.  Employees do not have the ability to sprinkle income to other family members, so why should a business owner? Full disclosure, I own two businesses and yes, I do what is legal under the current tax rules.  I also get business risk, believe me, but they are two totally unrelated issues.  You should own and run a business because the risk/return relationship is favourable.  You don't own a business with the expectation of the govt supporting your feasibility by allowing the owner to sprinkle income to kids.  It's not just doctors, it is also lawyers, accountants, business owners of private companies, etc..  The govt doesn't owe you a special tax break that others don't get (deferred income).  The govt shouldn't allow you expense deductions that others don't get (i.e. write off phone bills, home office, car usage, meals, computers, etc..).

Comment: Friend, I think you confuse two related but different matters.

The INS section you cite has to do with fraud in the *crossing* of the U.S. border. That can be either a civil or a criminal matter. And if criminal, as with all criminal cases, the U.S. bears the burden of proving the fraud. It is insufficient to merely demonstrate that the U.S. has not authorized entry as that fails to demonstrate fraud within the meaning of the text of the code. So, no, unless the alien knowingly obtained and used, for example, a fake green card to enter the U.S. initially, this section does not apply. More commonly, they've overstayed a lawful entrance.

Instead, most immigration cases are "unlawful presence" matters, which are not criminal, and focus instead on whether the alien has a demonstrable claim to be here. For example, the U.S. has treaty obligations requiring that it not deport minors who can show a likelihood of harm or persecution if returned to their home country.

Comment: Setting aside all the sound and fury, here are the facts:

- The City has already built or committed to build over half of the rail project.
- Polls show the majority of Oahu residents don't want to quit now but rather want the full 20-mile rail project to be completed.
- Given that, our elected officials have an obligation to get it done as efficiently as possible, without bankrupting the local economy.
- The total cost of the project to the local economy depends on the financing method, with the hotel room tax imposing the least burden on local taxpayers, the property tax imposing the most, and the excise tax surcharge falling somewhere in between.
- Only the legislature has the authority to authorize additional funding for the project from the hotel room tax or the excise tax or some combination of the two; if it fails to act the City will have to fall back on the property tax which is the worst option.

Based on the above the legislature needs to reconvene and MAKE A DECISION.

Now, he is unable to practice dentistry, unable to collect EI, his private disability insurance only pays him $5,000/month (at least he bought some!), yet he still has over $240,000 in student loans. Long story short, he's screwed. His options for paying back his loan are incredibly bleak, unless he returns to school and obtains another degree, incurring further debt, and how do we know if he will even be able to work again?

Also, we have a massive amount of professional fees and insurances to pay, so that if we ever do have an unfortunate event and get sued, we won't be starving. Comment: Canadians pay much higher airport taxes (fees) than Americans. Largely because US airports are operated by their Federal government and subsidized. What I can't support is the notion that a for-profit company would run a public transportation hub. That will certainly drive up the cost for no other reason than making some shareholder richer. We need look no further than Ontario's Highway 407 for which the Ontario government has given an ironclad, 99 year lease to a consortium of foreign and domestic companies to run it as a profit. A complete disaster for Ontario's 905 region commuters.

Comment: The government isn't taking it. The landowner never had the right to restrict access in the first place. If the owners don't like it, they should have done more research before buying the property. This same issue comes up in California constantly.

Comment: You can find information on most any 2018 plan, anywhere by starting here;
https://ratereview.healthcare.gov/
You'll need to choose "ACA compliant", "Alaska", and an effective start date of 1/1/2018.
When you look up a specific plan, you'll see a link on that page labeled "Issuer's Redacted Actuarial Memorandum". This PDF is the meat of the rate justification. Unfortunately, this year they blacked out almost all the data which would allow a person to make an informed public comment of the proposed rates. Regarding the only Alaska individual market plan, I found one very worrisome detail on page 6. For 2018 all non-emergency care outside of Alaska and Washington will be considered "out of network". This a huge change from 2017 when Alaskans had access to the nationwide "Blue Network" (BCBS) as in-network providers. Why would they do this? Sometimes the best care for a complicated condition is outside, and it's usually cheaper anyway. Also interesting was cost of the TrumpTax on page 3.

Comment: Given the limited # of characters it is, as even you might appreciate, impossible to "TELL THE WHOLE STORY."

In brief, Lincoln had an array of threats, from secessionists in the Border States to abolitionists who felt that he wasn't doing enough, to numerous politicians and journalists who were highly critical of his choices to lead the Northern Armies.  Burnside, Pope, McClellan, Hooker, Rosecrans gave plenty of ammunition to those who believed that Lincoln was unfit to be president.

When these journalists made too many overtures about making peace with the South, or gave up information which Lincoln thought could benefit the South, or found too much fault after disasters such as Fredericksburg or Chancellorsville, Lincoln had them jailed.  Estimates range from 2K - 15K.

It's important to note also that Lincoln was also a scofflaw regarding Habeus Corpus. Prior to 1863 only Congress could withhold it, but as the Merryman case proved, Lincoln again ignored the law for his own ends.

Comment: Wrong.  Cats and commensal rodents (house mice, Pacific, Norway and brown rats) are always found together.  Niagra Falls, for example, has more stray and feral cats than people.  The Orkin Exterminator Co. voted them Canada's second "rattiest" city last year.  Only Toronto was worse, and there are TNR colonies throughout that city.  Everywhere they've been introduced cats and commensal rodents form balances of sustainable numbers for the benefit of precisely ONE organism--not the cats, not the rats, and certainly not us humans.  Their purpose is to perpetuate the reproductive cycle of Toxoplasma gondii, which can only reproduce in feline digestive tracts.  Infected cats shed hundreds of millions of T. gondii oocysts when they defecate, which causes profound neurochemical changes in the rodents they infect--they're attracted to the scent of cat-pi$$, which hastens their return to feline digestive tracts to complete the cycle.  Cats don't control rodents--they ATTRACT them.

Comment: I have, for a long time, supported all measures of transparency in disclosing of trailer fees. However, I definitely do not support the banning of them.

The decision as to how mutual fund clients will pay their advisors should be the clients decision.

I have asked more than half of my clients whether they would prefer to pa me by invoice rather than the current trailer fee arrangement. To date, not one has indicated a preference to pay by invoice.

If the clients aren't in favor of this ban, then who is being served by this disruption?

The regulators know very well that smaller clients (anyone with less than $50,000 accounts) will simply be kicked to the curb in a fee for service model. These people frequently need the most advice on savings, debt service, and insurance products. 

This development is being driven by the banks, They have lost a lot of business to advisors who offer customized service to their clients and they are exerting influence on the regulators to get it back.

Comment: Great article.

Weinstein is redundant.  The details don't matter.  We know the dynamics of abusive personalities, that bullies are common, and that sexual harassment happens to every woman.  

But understanding our normal responses to abusive personalities is vital.  

Whether it's a real wolf or a human predator, our response is flight or fight.  Then we push the memory back and move on.  That's not minimizing, but to not fuhgettaboutit would be to live in fear, which is crippling.

So, speaking to women:  Trust your gut response.  And you don't have to come forward, but tell at least one trusted friend.

To predators:  You don't understand gossip.  Women do.  It's how we protect ourselves and it's powerful.  Don't think you're getting away with it just because you can't see the whispering crowd watching for evidence.

To us:  What's fair is to say what you know and how you know it.  Gossip has its risks, but until somebody has a better idea, ignoring it is what's unethical.

Comment: Canada is internationally obligated to adjudicate Convention refugee claims from persons IN Canada (as confirmed by the 1985 Singh case).

However a person appearing at a Port of Entry is not IN Canada by a technical legal definition so the obligations are not triggered.  As a result they can be sent back to the USA.

As I said it is the federal government exploiting a narrow technical loophole and it only applies to those claimants arriving from the US.  The Safe Third Country Agreement is the technical loophole and an exception to the usual rule.

Comment: AGW is nothing but FRAUD only the mentally challenged believe in.

A simple greenhouse test:

- 20x20x8' greenhouse has 3,200 cubic feet
- The amount of CO2 is 1.28 cubic feet
- Does any grown sane adult honestly believe adding or removing 1 cubic foot of CO2 from the greenhouse is going to magically change the temperature by 2C?

If this was true why would anyone need to pay for energy to heat their house? All they would need to do is put a clear bubble on their roof and fill it with 100% CO2.

- The amount of CO2 increase since 1960 is equal to 7x7x7" in the greenhouse. Does anyone think this makes a difference?

- The fact is 224 cubic feet of CO2 is required to make the greenhouse temperature rise by 1C, about 70,000 PPM.

MSM and governments are scam artists, brainwashing the ignorant masses with fairy tales while they are taxed into oblivion.

Comment: As of yet, there is no evidence that traffic accidents have gone up in states that have legalized cannabis. 

Yes, more fatally injured drivers are testing positive, but testing has gone up and the studies reporting these positives are quick to point out that cannabis is detectable for days or weeks following ingestion and that the positives do not indicate that the motorists were impaired or even blameworthy for the accidents that killed them. Nor is there any evidence that usage rates have gone up where cannabis has been legalized.

Cannabis is an economic substitute for alcohol, so when cannabis use goes up, drinking and DUI accidents go down.

ER "mentions" and poison control calls have gone up, in whole or in part where cannabis has been legalized because people in those jurisdictions are not as afraid to mention cannabis. Dutch consumers, for example, are more candid than Filipino consumers about cannabis, because Filipino consumers face extrajudicial death squads.

Comment: Frazer, I agree with you.  But I would like to see them lift the ban for commercial fishermen in the monument.  Keep the monument intact but open it up to Hawaii's fishery, that includes longlining, trolling and bottom fishing.  Compared to many foreign fisheries, Hawaii is one of the most documented and researched fisheries in the world.  What many don't know is there are likely illegal foreign boats fishing there now that go unreported or unregulated.  While a majority think it's easy for our longliners to simply move grounds, fishing doesn't work that way.  Our local supply drops, seafood wholesalers are forced to bring in inferior foreign product with little to no health regulations.  Example: hep A tainted scallops from the PI.  It will get supplemented from elsewhere.   

Longlining doesn't affect corals and they have very minimal by catch interactions.  The idea of MPAs does sound good but there is no hard scientific evidence that proves these monuments work.

Comment: This assumes the 'renter' is disciplined enough to invest the cash properly earning at least 6-7% per annum rate of return.

Comment: LOL.
Why do you non-science/engineer types always grab wrong data and present it as facts? Seriously.

Because, a typical base is about 30x50x20 (ft), which ~1000 cubic yards. A cubic yard is about 2 tons, so, that means that it is 2000 tons, NOT 30,000 tons. It is not even CLOSE so that you put.

Now, you assume that coal is what is used to heat the cement, yet, that is wrong. Electricity is all that is required. As such, the REAL issue is what is the grid doing.
1) http://blogs.ei.columbia.edu/2012/05/09/emissions-from-the-cement-industry/
"Producing a ton of cement requires 4.7 million BTU of energy, equivalent to about 400 pounds of coal, and generates nearly a ton of CO2. "
2) but, our grid, is NOT 100% coal. It is currently less than 30% coal, but we will go with 30.
SO, 400 lbs x .30 x 2000 = 240,000 LBs of coal, or 120 tons.

Comment: Thanks for yours, Michael. Here is what I mean:

Anything we might do to fix this problem will impact the economy. There is no way around that. However, if you look at the work done by ISER, they note that the worst thing for the overall economy would be to implement all of these measures at the same time (taxes, dividend reduction, cuts, etc.) That doesn't mean postponing the conversation, but simply phasing in various elements in a thoughtful and coordinated manner. 

Credit rating agencies are not concerned as much with our lack of new revenue generation as they are from our lack of an actual plan. It is the uncertainty they are reacting to, not the deficit itself.

What we need to do is close a significant portion of the deficit this year, but to also make real decisions around how we plan to close the rest, even if that occurs in subsequent years. There will no doubt be plenty to dislike in any real solution. But an imperfect plan today is better than almost any plan tomorrow.

Comment: In the long-term use of opioids for chronic non–cancer-related pain, the proven analgesic efficacy must be weighed against the following potential problems and risks: well-known opioid side effects, including respiratory depression, sedation, constipation, and nausea; inconsistent improvement in functioning; opioid-induced hyperalgesia; adverse hormonal (lowers testosterone) and immune effects of long-term opioid treatment; a high incidence of prescription opioid abuse behaviors; and an ill-defined and unclarified risk of iatrogenic addiction.- Ballantyne JC. Opioids for chronic nonterminal pain. South Med J 2006;99:1245–1255

Comment: The argument about maintenance fees being unaffordable is shocking to me. It's common for inclusionary-zoned buildings (like the one I lived in DC from 2009 - early 2016) to scale the maintenance fees just as the prices are. For example, my condo building was in one of the hottest areas of the city, with about 1/3 affordable units reserved for <50% median income, with their maintenance fees around $15 to $25 per month. The rest of us paid hundreds per month, and the Board is not allowed to change that fee structure. This is such a no-brainer. Has no one in city government actually looked at how other cities do this?

Comment: Oregon has an atypical dog bite statute that holds dog owners strictly liable for the payment of  "economic damages." Oregon Revised Statutes, section 31.360 subdivision (1) provides that "[f]or the purpose of establishing a claim for economic damages, as defined in ORS 31.710 (Noneconomic damages), in an action arising from an injury caused by a dog: (a) The plaintiff need not prove that the owner of the dog could foresee that the dog would cause the injury; and (b) The owner of the dog may not assert as a defense that the owner could not foresee that the dog would cause the injury."

There is always the possibility of using deadly physical force in defense of oneself or others if a reasonable person perceives your dog to be a threat.

Comment: Budget containment & budget cutting is the ONLY leg of the 3-legged Alaska Finance stool that the Legislature has taken any action on at all- And as you say, much has already been cut, & more cuts will likely come over the next 1-2 years. But while "cuts-only" may suit their personal interests, they are behaving with economic insanity & total fiscal recklessness if we hope to still have a functioning State in three short years---- 

The revenues you seek from non-oil are small from each sector. The cuts to oil tax credits make sense. And maximizing the size of the Permanent Fund, then making use of the sustainable interest it earns to pay for the bulk of government services meets the original purpose of the Fund. This 3-legged stool approach gives us long-term financial stability and an effective, efficient approach to paying for quality Alaska  services for all Alaskans. A fine plan! Comment: Yes , there is a history of environmental issues with the military but the military here in HI does have conservationists and active restoration efforts, in many regards they are better stewards than the state has been. The military drives the clean energy initiatives and actively participates.  They have programs such as RECP, Resident Energy Conservation Program, units and programs dedicated to conservation, and more. In fact a few Hawaii bases and units were awarded conservation awards. https://www.fws.gov/news/ShowNews.cfm?newsId=9013CC69-AC51-92DC-7455AAC0221F93F3

Is the military perfect? Absolutely not, but they are trying and finger pointing isn't helping them become better. We must first self-reflect and see where we can improve before blaming another group. We as citizens and a state have done a poor job of being stewards of the land and water. We could learn a thing or two from the Native Hawaiians in that regard.

Comment: "Teaching driving has been left up to parents"

That depends on the age of the student.

This past June, my eldest got his instruction permit right after his 15th birthday, since he, his mother, and I want him to get his license as soon as possible. By law, he has to have:
* 30-hour classroom instruction
* 6-hour certified training
* Currently working on (and logging) 50 hours of practice

The 30-hour classroom instruction was required to get his permit before age 15.5 years. The 6-hour behind-the-wheel training will be required to get his license before age 16.5 years.

If we'd waited 6 months, the 30-hour requirement would've been reduced to 4 hours. Then, since he couldn't get his license until age 16.5 (if under age 18, you have to have a permit for at least 12 months), the 6-hour certified training would've gone away.

The 50 hours of practice, logged and signed by a parent, are required to get a license before age 18.

Comment: Re: "Race"
Mr. Morse's letter has a noble intent but contains a flaw: while the taxonomic term "race" is not meaningful for classification members of our species,  "race" is still useful in classification of other animal species and is generally used, when needed, to talk about superficial differences between members of subspecies. Why is "race" not useful for meaningful for classifying members of Homo sapiens? It is because we can move around the world and breed with any other member of our species thereby producing a continuum of variation, and we have been doing this for at least many hundreds of thousands of years. This is why people often find very interesting combinations of ancestry after they send $100 and a swab of DNA off to a lab.

Comment: Greetings, John. I met you 40 years ago. 
My favorite place will always be the Copper Valley. Out in the wilderness. The vast panorama of the valley on a warm summer afternoon. The spectacular Wrangell Mountains cloaked in pristine white, soaring up into the blue sky as they have been since creation.  Miles and miles of endless silence but for a mouthy magpie and a couple of nosy camp-robbers. The scent of blueberries and spruce needles, leaves rustling in the warm breezes and more endless peace. An eagle floats up above and I find myself dozing in the warm sun.  A lone black bear pads past , not noticing or caring about me. Yep, it's the Copper Valley for me, boys!  Raw, uncut Alaska at its best. 
I still gotta figure out how I'm gonna get back down that hill to my cabin. 
But that can wait awhile. I'll just sit here a few more minutes...

Comment: I just read this article with great interest.  As an advocate for families with missing loved one, I wish this money could go into taking action now on the many recommendations already made in past inquiries and reviews.  I'd also like to inform the public that there are little or no supports for any families with missing loved ones.  I know this first hand when my son Daniel went missing in Nov. 2011.   

It's time for our country to develop a national Missing Persons framework (model) to support ALL families with missing loved ones, giving consistent supports, searches and investigations of ALL missing person cases.   Although the inquiry has implemented family liasion units, this is only for a number of identified families and only for the duration of the inquiry.  This is not enough.  A national Missing Persons framework would ensure that necessary supports and services are implemented and available to all families of missing loved ones.  Do you agree?

Comment: I disagree with Mr Toope’s implication that Canada is fearful. More accurately, it is flailing; too many governments, too little competence, and too much comfort in reliving past (questionable) glory. 
Therefore I find his three suggestions of where Canada should “spend its various forms of capital", at best, unrealistic.
Claiming Canadian experience gained nearly three decades ago on the land mines file, when the internet was in its infancy, puts Canada in a position to lead global efforts on cyberspace threats, which increasingly concern every person on earth, is nonsensical.
Canada has earned an international reputation for managing reasonably well the selection and reception of some thousands of immigrants and refugees. But, the jury is still out on how well Canada is integrating new arrivals.
Canada’s reputation for credible banking  and financial probity, is fine, but Canada does NOT have a good reputation for corporate social responsibility at its mining companies. 
Know thyself

Comment: Ignorant ? Read the paper as I have for the last 60 years. Every single year in Alaska there's more than one story of a pilot taking innocent passengers to their death.   In around 95 percent of the crashes pilot error is the cause. Over and over and over again it's stupid stuff---the pilot KNEW the weather was bad but headed out into it anyways , the pilot over loaded the airplane , the pilot didn't check his fuel , and the list goes on and on .  As has been said for years concerning Alaska and aviation---if you've lived any length of time at all in Alaska you knew or know of someone who died in a plane crash.  That say's it all concerning the cowboy attitude of Alaska pilots.  The only reason I comment on this subject is I hate to see all the innocent deaths .  When I pilot rolls the dice and he's the only one on board , that's how it goes. But when their stupidity and risk taking takes innocent lives---that's terrible. And it happens way too often in Alaska.

Comment: I suspect that rape kits likely to solve rape cases have already been tested.   I further suspect that untested rape kits are untested because DA's have deemed the potential information content to be nil.  At a taxpayer cost of $1300 per test, there need be some critical analysis of whether testing rape kits deemed to have low evidence value is wise.  Those who demand testing every rape kit may find that doing so has the unanticipated consequence of reducing the number of women who have the opportunity to actually have rape medical exams performed.  When DA's know that each rape test must be fully processed regardless of situation and other evidence so as to deplete DA budget, we may see rules governing the administration of rape tests tightened to exclude cases where such tests are deemed low value. 

It would be greatly appreciated if the RG could do a follow-up when the current multi-million dollar testing is complete to see if any benefit was obtained.

Comment: AJ, you are conflating the work of Arthur Laffer with supply side Economics, and misrepresenting one of his main tenets.

Laffer did not advocate lowering taxes as a way to stimulate economic growth as a central principle.
He proved empirically and scientificially that there is a level (percentage or proportion) of tax rates beyond which the actual taxes collected will be lower than if the tax rate had been kept at the lower level.
In other words, continually raising taxes can be self-defeating.

Under the socialist labour government in Britain in the 1960's the top marginal tax rate was 83%, plus a 15% "Super tax" = 98% on unearned income.

98 per frikkin cent!

How many people do you think actually paid that kind of tax, and how much super tax was collected?

If you will forgive me interjecting a comment...

I think you have a very valid point, when you say that priests would be less vulnerable if they had their own homes -- and many do. That said, I believe many, many priests take the approach they do, not because they are unaware, but because they choose to accept that risk as the price they pay to be the priests they want to be. 

A lot of laypeople do not realize (and a subset don't care) that the present climate creates many difficulties for priests. I know priests who, when traveling, never stay at a friend or family member's home, because there are children under 18 in the home. They avoid using public bathrooms. They cannot welcome families into their rectories if there are children. They have to worry about how a hug might be construed. These are priests who haven't done anything wrong, and don't want to be ruined by a suspicion.

Comment: The city was not "almost lost" in 1997. The province squeeked the water through using only the lower deck that carries 90,000cu/ft sec.  The Red River was maxed to 110,000cu/ft sec. Dynamiting the bridges crossing the Red River floodway diversion and clay sealing the upper deck openings they passed through would have provided an additional 25,000cu/ft sec. of capacity if need. The 48 km floodway diversion around Winnipeg was enlarged by 25%  and the new bridges are now domed in shape to accommodate a one in 750 year event. Both the original construction and the expansion were 50/50 cost shared between the provincial/federal governments.

The original system is extensive and protects the majority of urban centres of Manitoba as far as the Sask border. Eg. Shellmouth dam/reservoir.  Recent unregulated draining of slews, marshes and lowlands by Sask farmers is responsible for the rare but recent breaches of defences of rural communities in western Manitoba, and particularly North Dakota.

Comment: I suggest that you read Paul's Letter to the Romans---Chapter 16.  In it Paul recommends Phoebe---a deacon [not deaconess], and asks that she be given every that she may require.  Phoebe, in fact as a patron, underwrote the mission to Spain---which was important to Paul.  It was why Paul was writing to the Romans in the first place.  Paul then greets Prisca [nick-name for Priscilla] and her husband Aquila---who worked side-by-side with Paul.  This couple heard Apollos speak boldly about Jesus in the Jewish synagogue---but not correctly[Acts 18:24-26].  Luke writes, "they took him aside and explained the way of God to him more accurately" [Acts 18:26].

Paul commends Mary, who worked very hard in Rome.  Paul calls Andronicus and Junia, his relatives, early Christians and prominent among the apostles.
These women DID speak in church.  They did teach adults and they did put their lives on the line for the sake of Christ.
  
None of the apostles would recognize the Church today.

Comment: There are some things where the game is rigged against the young but I don't see this as it. For each friend you have in their 50's and 60's who won the lottery by owning there is one who didn't -  which is worse being 20 and suddenly having an uphill battle to own, or being 50 and suddenly having an uphill battle to own? The 50 year old has no meaningful chance to become an owner and so in two decades will suddenly be facing retirement, and a fixed and reduced income, in a place with sky high rents that keep going up faster than inflation. The 20 year old has 45 years to prepare for that eventuality. In reality for both the likely solution is that they will be forced to move somewhere new, away from friends and family. Is that harder for the older or the young? I'd argue that it is demonstrably harder for the older person.
I think victim-sizing, no matter how popular these days, is a loser's game that just plays up divisiveness and creates unnecessary alienation that hurts everybody.

Comment: And I've worked with folks (primarily families) in those motels directly for years. Very few of the folks there are actually subsidized. During the cold weather season some folks on days where the temp drops below 20 at night get a voucher, some folks get temporary assistance from churches and assistance agencies, and some individuals get assistance because they are felons or have other specific needs. These hotels are not great. They are falling apart, but they also house a tremendous amount of families whose rental histories preclude them from renting, especially in this market, in any part of the Denver metro area. Every single family I've worked with there (at least 100 at this point in my career) has had jobs, above or under the table, to pay for their rent. Or they were employed by the Kings Inn owners in exchange for rent. Subsidized they are not.

Comment: Always 10 days late for the debate, but anyways here I go.

On my reserve in BC our water(and wastewater)  treatment operators belong to the same provincial certification organization, the Environmental Operators Certification Program (EOCP), that any other operator from any community in BC would belong to. And to maintain their standing, each operator is required to accumulate a certain level of training credits over two year periods for the duration of their EOCP membership. Our operator was one of two First Nation Level III Water Distribution operators in all of BC, and his water is as good as it gets.

Bad water treatment isn't a First Nation thing; it's a poverty thing, it's a traumatized community thing, it's a predatory consultant thing.  It's so many things that building a new multi-million plant couldn't solve all the issues plaguing First Nations water

Comment: I helped a friend purchase a used truck last year.  We found a good specimen in Vaughan, took the truck for an inspection and was ready to purchase it the next day.  I did some basic research...red book pricing and simple comparisons online.  When we started negotiating, the salesman assumed I was willing to pay their asking price ($44,000 range).  I asked him to justify the price when the red book price was in the range of $41,000 and other dealers were pricing the same make and model and year at $38-42,000 range.  He took my concerns to the "manager" and we left after ten minutes of waiting (I didn't thing they still do this today, but...).  The salesman was upset with us for not waiting!!!  Approximately two weeks later we found a better truck from a customer of the dealer (not imported from the US) and under $40,000.  The used car business here is in great need of an overhaul...

Comment: "Hockey was more violent in the 1970s". Well, yes and no. I can actually remember what hockey was like then. Head-on, open ice body checks were the norm. Padding was lighter, so checkers had to be careful of injuring themselves. The best defenders had mastered the poke check. Fights broke out. Slashing happened. Without helmets, players got cut and lost teeth. But then the game changed.  Now, a check is one player smashing another into the boards, usually after the puck has gone somewhere else ("finishing the check"). Open ice play is rare, mad scrambles are the norm. Padding has been weaponized.  So the comparison is invalid.

Comment: No, the map shows three stations on the Bering sea showing positive sea level rise and two of those have positive confidence intervals. The CI's on the Beaufort sea are large enough that it's a toss, however the dataset only spans 25 years which is why they're so high. Either way the trend is positive. If you had read the paper I posted you would have noted that the Canadian Beaufort is also showing positive SLR.

That particular paper also examines 60 stations on the Russian side spanning the Kara to the Chukchi. The trend in the Chukchi starting in 1950 is also positive. 

You might not know this, but you can also calculate sea level (known as zeta in Physical Oceanography) based off of salinity and temperature. We have been collecting T and S data in the Beaufort, Chukchi and Bering for a longer time and over a greater area than the scattered tidal stations that exist. They also show positive SLR.

Again, the only place shown on the map with negative SLR is the Gulf.

Comment: The followers of the 1962 Mass think they are getting the Mass of St. Pius V. They really are not. Despite Pius’ injunction that not a word be changed, the Mass of St. John XXIIII is no more and no less the Mass of Pius as the Norvus Ordo (in either translation). The more troubling action by Benedict was allowing the reimposition of the old translation of the responses of the Norvus Ordo, which are not far (And with your Spirit) from the old form. As for the old form itself, I have no problem with nostalgia. I have friends who are in the Socieity for Creative Anachronism or are Civil War reenactors. Still, while I am tolerant, because the Mass when said is real, I fear it being turned into an historical curiosity or attempted counter-revolution (it won’t win as the latter).

Comment: Thank you for your kind reply, Looking for Solutions2.  But, what is "ES"?  enlisted service?

It may sound as though I am bitter (I had many bad experiences with overbearing officers and NCO's) but overall my duty in Korea (19 months, 1/1/68 to 8/1/69) as first a tech, and then a site commander at a remote mountaintop radio relay station, was one of the formative experiences of my adult life, and I left Korea with regret, having connected with the beauty of the people and the land.  When I became a 21-year-old sergeant responsible for a small station of a dozen techs and an equal number of Korean support workers, the mission was first and the welfare of the men was second.  I can hardly believe that I did it at that young age, but it gave me the confidence later to run projects for Dow Corning, and later, as an independent contractor.

The army was full of various kinds of SOB's, but I also had the privilege of serving under some very fine officers and NCO's.  But I chose my MOS well.

Comment: It doesn't even have to be hard. All that red-tape the dear Premier is so upset by (because how dare we want those houses to be safe and not destroy precious environmental resources without due care  right ?) has such a ridiculously easy solution.
Cape Town is filled with developers desperate to build - there's new developments going up everywhere. Three within 2km's of my house ! They already DO all those things FOR you. And Cape Town is in charge of zoning and licensing. Currently they are talking of 'affordable housing' becoming a condition for new development permits.
Cut the crap - just make it a requirement that 50% of all the dwellings in a new development MUST be sold to government (at a capped fee no higher than what government could have built it for) which HAS to be given to people on the list.
It puts the poor NEXT DOOR to the rich, undoing spatial apartheid (and close to jobs). And you'll have more free homes than you can give away.

Comment: You are right.   In many countries only tourists tip. In doing so, they upset the local economy and change it for everybody.   In such cases, on my own I tip the amount natives would tip.  The tour companies suggest tips because they want the guides and drivers to be happy to work with their company.  If their groups are known as poor tippers, the best ones will refuse to work for them.  I follow the tour companies guidelines but tip nothing if the service was poor and would tip over the top end of the range for extra service.  I have been know to increase my tip if I know that others (who can often easily afford it) are shorting on the tip.  Another thing, if the tour company takes care of tips, they pay it to the tour agency in country and the entire tip is not passed on to the guides and drivers.  Best to tip directly.  Also, I do not partake in group tipping, always give my tips separately in an envelope and discreetly thanking the person personally.

Comment: I wonder how many people reacting in agreement to comments ripping on the medical profession for prescribing pain meds have ever themselves been in debilitating pain.  Involved in a bad accident in 1990 that resulted in being hospitalized in a coma, leading to 9 operations, and ending up being entered into a pain management program approved by the Mayo Clinic and Dr.'s at John Hopkins, I suspect I may know a bit more than the average citizen on this issue.  There are three basic reasons for the problem with opioids.  First, almost no money is spent on pain medicine research.  Second, it is very difficult to diagnose pain (you can't 'see' the problem).  And third, the majority of existing pain meds are addicting.  Is it abused?  Absolutely!  Are there alternatives?  Very few and only if you find doctors more interested in you then in the money.  So without more and better info, please cut the pain sufferer some slack.  Pain strong enough to bring daily tears makes finding happiness hard

Comment: Re: If we want to keep our guns, then we need to become a lot wiser about how we use them” PART 1

According to the CDC in 2013 there were about 11208 people murdered by firearms in the US which works out to about 31 people per day. These are the “word doctored” figures the news media and anti-gun folks like to publicize because people relate to the magnitude of those numbers and it sounds like a lot of people until you realize this is out of a population of 319 million Americans. In that context, it works out to about 1 person out of every 28,000 people being murdered by a firearm.  Dwell on the magnitude of your individual significance next time you are in a stadium with 28,000 people. To me, 1 in 28,000 is an acceptable cost to help ensure the security of a free state and the right to own a firearm that has harmed no one.

Comment: A bit of background. The apparently eye-popping fee is the result of the SECs Acquired Fund Fees requirement (implemented in 2014) which forces funds that own BDCs to report BDC's expenses as if they were their own. 
I've never quite fathomed out the SEC's rationale for this move but it had some ramifications in the early days, e.g. both Russel and S&P removed BDCs from their indices as a result.

Rgerdless, I believe that BDCs are worthy of consideration by those investors seeking primarily a robust yield and who have a moderately high risk tolerance. I've held a number for years (currently hold 9).

I would recommend, for those who are interested, investing directly in individual BDCs, not via an ETF.

Some names to consider are ARCC (current yield 9.3%), GSBD (8.0%), MAIN (7.1% - calculated taking into account the regular semi-annual supplemental dividends of $0.2750) , NMFC (9.4%). Their Investor Presentations and latest quarterly reports are a good starting point for research.

Comment: "Coming in and breaking the union and offering less money or else they're out of a job is definitely firing them."

No, it's not firing anyone, because the employees were never hired by the new owners. The business changed hands, and when businesses change ownership, there is *never* a guarantee that the employees will keep their job - or their pay.

I used to be a federal contractor. This is how life works, whether you like it or not. I worked with people on other contracts whose contract changed ownership, and they faced a 15% pay cut. That is what happens when someone new takes ownership.

Did it occur to you that the compensation package and union benefits may have been financially untenable? Amazon Fresh delivers all the way down Issaquah-Hobart road now, and I strongly suspect that the market was losing business as a result.

I hope that this community is absolutely thrilled that more people are now out of work and we have an expensive abandoned building right downtown. Good job!

Comment: Part 2
The novus ordo restores the essential three part action of this type of sacrifice to the visible realm in as much as (1) we all offer the food of bread and wine in the offertory procession, (2) the clergy "confects" the Eucharist (converting it from ordinary food to sacred food), and (3) we all communally eat and drink of the consecrated gifts. 

These elements were present, of course, in the Tridentine ritual, but the essential role of the faithful bringing the gifts and sharing fully in the meal by eating and drinking have been rendered physically visible in bodily gesture. Since the same visible action (leiturgia, public action) was equally visible in the early liturgy, this aspect of the novus ordo is properly characterized as a "reform", a "restoration" of a ritual that had become "corrupt" in the sense that essential elements with obscured. 

"Assisting at mass" in my experience conjures images of the faithful as silent, non-essential observes at a sacred priestly ritual.

Comment: In comparison between a City Council race and a race for a seat in the House of Representatives, the buy-in for a House seat is typically cheaper than it is for a City Council seat. Reason being the size of the district. A Council district, in general, holds about 100,000 residents in the area. A House area typically has about 23,700 residents. 

So, currently, you see new challengers (or replacements) for City Council seats coming from the State Legislature - Manahan, Fukunaga, Kobayashi, Menor and Pine were all former state Legislators before they came over to the Council. They are able to make the jump quickly because they already have sources of money and adequate name recognition. In rare cases, such as Elefante for instance, their interface with the community along with strong support from the outgoing member gives the probie politician enough heft to run a successful campaign. 

Overall, folks like Dudley and Case face quite insurmountable, but not impossible, odds.

Comment: If I take payment from someone, promise something and don't deliver, that's fraud.  So how come companies can take pension contributions from employees, promise pension benefits and then just renege without any repercussions to the companies or their overpaid management?  How can they just avoid paying legally-mandated severance pay and get away with it?  Companies should be required to fully-fund their pension and severance liabilities (i.e. maintain assets equal to their liabilities and keep them separate from company assets) at all times.  As it is, if there's a shortfall in pension funding they are only required to develop a plan to get back to full funding eventually (they seldom do), and the regulators just go along with it.  As a former employee of a pension regulator, I was always amazed at this officially-sanctioned fraud.  If nothing else, pension and severance liabilities should at least be first on the list of priorities for payment upon company dissolution.

Comment: Strange frame in this story tends to obscure the story itself. Obviously, if these increases happened, the younger judges would benefit far greater over time because they would have a higher salary over more years.  That adds up! Younger employees who work for the state have in some sectors also benefitted greatly from the market-modernized pay scales that have been put in place over the last few decades. Those adjustments have lagged in some sectors for older workers. I don't know how it is for judges.

Younger state employees have lost retirement money (measured as percentage of salary replacement) relative to older workers as PERS retirement benefits have been reduced over time.

But the story just doesn't seem quite accurate. Salary and benefits increases benefit younger workers over time more than they do older workers, who receive the (compounded!) benefits for far fewer years.

So what's the point of pitting younger and older workers against each other anyway?

Comment: I just returned from a visit to the USCCB website looking at the listing for Prayers for Vocations. There are 2 Parent's prayers for vocations.One tilted more toward priesthood and one which names all four of the vocational calls, single, ordained, married, consecrated. There are 40 prayers for vocations with the majority of them slanted toward priesthood, and no mention of the other vocational calls. Today, it is still common among clergy to link vocational call as being synonymous with priesthood. Having served for several years in vocations ministry at a parish level it was an on going struggle over terms and titles. Then Bishop Sean O'Malley wrote the first prayer for the vocation of marriage as a vocation. And though Jesus was 'single' and obscure for 33 years there isn't a prayer for the vocation of single life. If Bishops are unable to even pray for the four vocations - how can they accompany a youth for unbiased discernment?

MMP dual candidature makes a doubly-safe seat system, denounced by the Welsh Richard report as denying voters the fundamental democratic right to reject candidates. (They recommended change to STV.) Italian parties over-represented by the FPTP vote double-claimed on representation, with "fake" or "decoy" parties, taking party list seats, as well. 
Despite Fair Votes Canada assurance to the contrary, MMP does not do away with strategic voting and wasted voting. No x-voting system can, whether plurally or proportionally counted. (e.g. see Swedish academic, Annika Freden.) 
Party-proportional counts deny individual liberty of choice; fraternity to transcend party divisions, and equality of all social groups afforded by a transferable vote.
Richard Lung. "Democracy Science" with links to 3 free e-books on election method and science.

Comment: Earnings income with the inclusion of the bottom 20% (maybe more) gives a distorted picture since this includes all manner of self employed and part time workers who may be working on an opportunistic basis or who entered or left the workforce part way through the year.

By Stats Canada definition this excludes EI income so excludes a significant amount of income for some persons who choose to work only part of the year.

More meaningful comparisons would be looking at earned incomes for persons who were employed fulltime.  That would tell a different story, especially around the bottom 20%.

If you want to look at everyone use Stats Can's "Total Income" numbers where the median is 1.5% higher than it is for "Employment Income".

It is wrong to imply a 'market failure' on incomes when you mix and match fulltime employment incomes with part time.

Comment: "R-factors are calculated from what Verum director of research Sean Rife and his colleagues call golden citations, which reference manuscripts that directly replicate a particular study. (The vast majority of citations—about 95%—just mention other papers.) A paper’s R-factor is the number of confirmatory golden citations divided by the sum of confirmatory and refuting golden citations. The more reproducible a study is, the closer its R-factor is to 1."

http://physicstoday.scitation.org/do/10.1063/PT.6.2.20171004a/full/

Comment: The state sells land all the time.  It's an ongoing process, but it's not a remedy.  The budget gap is $2.4Billion.  The state couldn't sell enough land at fair market value to close a $2.4B gap one year, let alone every year.  Go to the Alaska Department of Revenue website and find the Revenue Sources Book, which will show income from land sales.  Look at the RSBs for, say, the past five years to get an average of revenue from land sales.  Even if you could double the sales--which you couldn't--the revenue from land sales would still be woefully insufficient to close the budget gap.  Nobody wants to buy land that isn't surveyed, so the state would have to pay for that, and the state has other staff to manage sales so they're fair and legal.  Don't assume the state isn't constantly earnestly endeavoring to make money off state resources, incl. raw land (as well as oil, minerals, timber, water).  The state IS trying to make money, always has been.  No easy "remedy" has been overlooked.

Comment: I had a dream. I would get into a large  canoe, not made from birch bark, loaded with whiskey and blankets (basic supplies, not for trading along the way). In a early, calm dawn light I would begin to paddle from near Montreal to the Northwest territories, along a route perhaps taken by voyageurs 300 years ago, when Canada was new, pristine , and unspoiled in every regard. I often think of these men - roving adventurers of lake, stream and backwood. It was all backwood in those days, and a mis-step or errant paddling decision could cost you your life - and for many it did. No phones, rescue squad or paramedics in those days. It was root hog or die. The voyageurs, unknown, unsung, the intrepid wayfarers in a pathless land - true Canadian heroes, my heroes. What they did by deed and strength of character can only thrive in my imagination. Paddle on, men from an now unknown age in a then unknown country.

Comment: “Single studies like this need to be interpreted with great caution. Risk does not mean an inevitable outcome. Furthermore, an association does not necessarily mean cause. An association may reflect a causal link between autism and severe depression or the association may reflect a causal link between the medication and autism.

The global evidence is increasingly showing that the risk of untreated depression or anxiety perinatally on the foetus and infant, are likely to outweigh the risks of antidepressants on offspring outcomes. Balancing the risks is an important part of the decision to treat with antidepressants or not. This decision needs to be individualized and made collaboratively, as part of the consultation between the woman and her practitioner.” Dr Simone Honikman, Perinatal Mental Health Project (PMHP)

Comment: Since I believe that human life begins at conception, how can I "concede"---what right do I have to "concede"---anything that would be a death warrant for certain human beings? 

What I CAN concede, and many times have, is that reasonable people of good faith can disagree about whether a person worthy of protection exists from conception onward.  This is where Roe v. Wade went off the tracks. I hate to concede it, but I must: New York, California, Ohio, whatever---all have the right to say that abortion is always just fine! As an American, I accept that that's the democratic process. By the same token, it can go the other way, too---and the Roe Court had to turn legal pretzels (and do lasting damage to constitutional law far beyond the scope of abortion) in order to reach the conclusion it did. On this point, read a classic, "The Wages of Crying Wolf," by Jon Hart Ely, who personally supported the right to abortion.  It's worthy of a Pulitzer. May God inspire your search for the truth.

Comment: I get so tired of hearing "the addict won't change unless he wants to change."  It's true, and also trivial.  If he changes, that proves he wants to.  If he doesn't, that proves he doesn't.  Can you see how circular that is?  "Want" stands for a concept that is actually very hard to define, much less operationalize.  

Peggy Billingsley is the only one (so far) in this thread to put her finger on the central fact about addiction: like other mental illnesses,  it invariably involves intense internal conflict.  The addict is still himself, the person you've always known . . . and yet he isn't.  A sort of shadow self seems to have taken control of his behavior.  As countless recovered addicts and alcoholics can testify, it's possible to close the door on that false self.  Most of them acknowledge that some sort of intervention was crucial to their recovery.  As Johann Hari put it in his excellent study of addiction, "The opposite of addiction isn't sobriety but connection."

Comment: Charles, I think it's far too late. If the world stopped burning fossil fuels today, the planet would continue to heat to a catastrophic level, possibly at the expense of most life on Earth. That's no excuse for not trying to do as much as we can, because doing the right thing for its own sake is good enough, and you are correct, it is a moral issue. 

I've been following this subject for years, and humans have set in motion forces that we will not be able to undo, in the same way that we have no answers for the ongoing Fukushima disaster, which continues to dump 300 to 400 tons of radioactive water into the Pacific every day. In the 60s, when nuclear energy was unleashed on the world, engineers didn't have permanent answers for the radioactive waste. They assured everyone that by the time those spent fuel rods were a problem, engineers would find an answer. They haven't, and spent fuel rods and deteriorating storage is now a multi-thousand year problem.  Human hubris is a problem.

We are still a "young State" and there a number of laws and regulations that would benefit from review or adjustment to more accurately address real life circumstances.

Among them are to take the discussion too personally, the misuse of words and phrases to put another dow:, to come to argue, even, bully: to project onto those with whom we disagree our own failings (speck and log) and to stalk a poster for whom we have developed a, particular, disliking.

You're on your journey, EFC and I am on mine, I wish you well and hope you have the same wish for me.

Peace,

John David

Comment: This is an important study.  Of course,  for many years researchers have known that the teenager is a nocturnal being...with body rhythms that favor late night alertness and early morning grogginess.  This research has had virtually no impact on educational policy, the Board of Education, or even the Legislature.  Now we can calculate the number of hours of sleep, which is related, but not exactly the same.  The issue is not only how much they sleep, but when we demand full attention.   It is great that Kaimuki has had the flexibility to experiment.  Can this be translated into a policy for high school students?  Can research be linked to implementation across a system?   Individual and innovative risk takers may use it.  Perhaps the Board of Education could also become innovators as well.

Comment: Where is the Army? That is a question that should be directed at public sector unions, who thoroughly resent the military for the constraints the  military imposes on the ability of unionised membership to earn overtime. Military members never, never earn overtime, and while it is theoretically feasible for the federal government to present provincial governments with a bill for   federal aid, in practice this never happens. In the eyes of public sector unions, soldiers are nothing more than uniformed "scabs" that threaten their bargaining power and labour monopolies.

One of he great untold stories of the 1998 Quebec Ice Storm were the significant frictions that developed between the Army and Hydro Quebec workers, who were resentful of the Army's efficiency in recycling downed hydro wires and setting up makeshift transmission lines. The Army made them "look bad", highlighting the endemic corruption of the Quebec body politic and its penetration by organized crime interests.

Comment: Hi Amy,
I can understand why it sounds like this is what I was looking for - that was not my intention.  Let me be more clear! The reason I felt compelled to write about this is to fight the stigma of mental health care. While I greatly appreciate the confidential nature, it hurts us all to have mental health in this separate "unmentionable" category. When I look at much of what is going on in the world, I see underlying roots in mental health issues. I am often inundated by requests for referrals to good family therapists, child therapists, medication providers etc. Why not let the huge number of people in Anchorage who are using these providers and clinics give a consumer's opinion of their efficacy while also taking the category of mental health out of the shadows?

Comment: Nobody would go bankrupt, that's a silly assertion. For starters, there would be a spending cap and those funds would be limited to serious candidates who have enough support to get on the ballot. People get on the ballot now with hardly a dime in outside spending. 

As for funding petition drives, field offices, etc, that money would be less restricted and easily funded. Primary campaigns would hardly need to be regulated at all, given that they are not competing for government positions. Most petition drives are run by volunteers and those staffers who are paid can easily be compensated under the regulated candidate contribution framework than what we have now. 

I'm not sure where your third point is coming from. I suppose you're making the case that the money will be spent one way or another. I disagree. When campaigns were more tightly regulated, we didn't spend 2 billion dollars on elections. It's self-evident that we need more regulation and less money in politics.

Comment: As McGuigan said, Poloz's protests that the inflation target is symmetric is a bit of a joke as over the last four years, the time he has been Governor, the annualized rate of inflation has been 1.5%, substantially below the 2.0% target. In fact, there is no reason that the target should be set as high as 2.0%. The 2016 renewal of the inflation control agreement admitted as much. A 2.0% target now is like a 2.2% target at the time of the 2011 renewal agreement. A move to annual basket updates in the CPI would push the effective target rate up even higher, where there is no need to go. See my 2017 paper "Why the Bank of Canada's Target Rate of Inflation Should Be Lowered" for more information: 
http://economics.ca/2017/papers/BA0017-1.pdf

Comment: The similarities between all humans is in their 23 pairs of matched chromosomes made up of many thousands of genes.    We are bi-lateral, bipedal, have a head with a large, complex brain, a spine, a torso, two arms, two legs.  The main  difference is in the hormones--testosterone or estrogen/progesterone (the sex organs are built from the same system as can be seen in the development in the womb).  
The difference between men and women is in the 23rd chromosome--the XX chromosome has two complete pairs of genes; the  XY chromosome has about two-thirds matched genes and one-third is missing the matching genes in that chromosome--much like a Y is an X without one of the 4 arms..  

Yes, of course men and women are "different"-- but the similarities far outweigh the differences.
