Comment: Russell, Rover's Run has had three maulings that I know of, all involving brown bears. Two of the victims were bikers, one was running. No hikers have been injured on that trail. Rover's Run is closer to the creek than the two advanced downhill singletrack trails proposed in the park. But they aren't that much farther away, and the bears are relatively concentrated in the Spencer's Loop area by greater human activity in adjacent areas. Far North Bicentennial Park (with 4 maulings) and trails leading into it from nearby Chugach State Park (with 1 mauling) have more bear maulings than any comparable-sized area in Anchorage. At what point do we get to express our concern?

I wasn't comparing FNBP to Banff. I used the Banff study as the only example I knew where numbers of hikers and bikers were more or less known and a judgement could be made as to which user group had more bear encounters.

Comment: Thanks UC! We're glad you're here!  :)

The character limit is approximately two paragraphs long, but you're correct, there is no limit on the number of posts. We did originally have a longer character limit on comments, but received a lot of negative feedback during testing. We've found that posting a two-paragraph comment, then posting additional paragraphs as replies to that comment, has been a decent compromise, as the comments stay in order within the replies, and it gives others a chance to get a word in edgewise.  Thanks!

Comment: [... contin.]

Based on "slowing traffic" and creating a full sidewalk to increase "walkability," staff supported, and the Crest Drive Community Team recommended a fatal mistake that City Council approved -- reducing the pavement width below the adopted, minimum city street standard of 20 feet. 

Instead Crest Drive is the sole two-way street in the city that has 9-foot travel lanes.

The _minimum_ standard for a fire truck or other emergency vehicle is 10 feet. The Eugene Fire Code, which is based on the International Fire Code, _requires_ a "Fire Apparatus Access Lane" that has a minimum 20-foot wide pavement with a surface that can support 80,000 pounds.

I'm willing to bet that Gardner didn't manage the CDSD project so that all residents understood the critical need for Crest Drive to maintain a 20-foot wide pavement.
 
So, "walkability," the same abstract concept being used to justify the _staff_ proposal for the (now killed) SW-SAZ, requires on-the-ground facts, not new age hype.

Comment: In general, if I arbitrarily change the formula of a well known chemical reaction, the physical laws of the universe yield something OTHER than what the usual results would be. It is the same with language. That's why the Church based the formulae of the Mass on one well-known language that was the most widely known at the time, thereby ensuring that ALL priests, everywhere, would be saying the same thing, and more specifically, the mystical result would be the same. IF we had been more careful about things back then, ARAMAIC would have been the natural choice, for then we would be saying things, and they would have exactly the same meaning, as Christ said and intended, even if it would have been without His full understanding and comprehension. Latin was the next best choice, as it was spoken and written throughout most of the then "civilized" world of Western Europe. Words have power. Moving to the vernacular was bad enough - changing time-honored formulas will be much, much worse.

Comment: Hey Dr. M, your head is in a dark spot. Did you not read that I don't deny climate change. I used your rationale of the dynamics of climate is complex influenced by many variables, not driven only by CO2 as the climate change advocates/zealots state... The end of the little Ice Age was not caused by CO2 emitted by the onset of the Industrial Revolution. Industry in those days didn't add any significant CO2 to the atmosphere. CO2 in the atmosphere was a fairly steady 280 ppm until about 1950 when it began to rise up into the present level of about 400 ppm. What probably ended the Little Ice Age was an increase in solar activity or a change in ocean currents.    
These same influences began the general retreat of the glaciers! THE POINT I THINK YOU DON'T GET IS THIS HAPPENED PRIOR TO 1950 WHEN CO2 INCREASED. Also the largest volume of ice lost by far on the Mendenhall as well as the Grand Pacific Glacier of Glacier Bay happened prior to 1950, when CO2 levels were low. Comprende Amigo?

By Bridget Mary Meehan, ARCWP
The Franciscan School of Theology's focus on God's extravagant love and abundance taught by Saint Bonaventure and John Duns Scotus provides an alternative to Atonement Theology taught by St. Anselm and St. Thomas Aquinas.

Comment: taken to be essential to the genre of poetry. Hebrew poetry instead uses parallelism as it core poetic concept. For instance, a Hebrew couplet most often says the same thing in the first and second line, but in different words. That is not the only type of parallelism, but it is the most common. Providentially, this means that the poetry of the psalms translates easily across languages; something that is much more difficult in just about any other type of poetry. BTW, note that since poetry is a genre we are familiar with, no one expects the narrative assertions in the psalms to be necessarily historical...we all know that the genre poetry is not history, so we are unperturbed by assertions that may not reflect reality...it's poetry. 

Re: Isaiah. Scholars distinguish at least three authors in Isaiah, referred to as First, Second, and Third Isaiah. The material collected together in what we call the Book of Isaiah by later editors covers a significant time span, from before the exile..

Comment: Assumption always made is that a mutual fund is going to have the performance of an index or worse - simply not the case. When markets are virtually at all time highs - it is easy to make the case for the best index as it is really a growth equity mutual fund with no downside support. Watch what happens when markets go down. We have seen a couple of small examples where large ETF's have had horrible trading days. The market makers were not there. We'll see what happens when it gets real ugly. Also it has  not been difficult to outperform the TSX for the last 5 or 10 year time period. Many Canadian based mutual funds have outperformed their respective TSX index. However that wasn't the case during commodity bull run of 2001 -2008. Bond funds are another example of outperformance. I cannot recall anyone going through the last big downturn saying boy I wished I had an index fund. They were upset on both accounts but one generally outperformed the other - unless you were buying the losers.

Comment: Here is some more high school level physics.
Since the heat capacity of sea water is a lot higher than air above it. The planet is about 70% covered by water .The sea water drives the atmospheric temperature ,not the other way around.
air @ 1158 J/(kg*C)   sea water @3850 J/(kg*C)
When you figure in the total mass of the oceans compared to the atmosphere  , the ocean has a 1000X's the heat capacity of the atmosphere.
The top 3.2m of the worlds oceans has the same heat capacity of the entire atmosphere.
So what drives the oceans temp.'s , that would be solar energy from the sun.It penetrates deep enough for warming down to 100m to 200m , that's well beyond the 3.2m level . Atmospheric CO2 , man made or other wise(via claims of AGW) has nothing to do with it.
see:http://eesc.columbia.edu/courses/ees/climate/lectures/o_atm.html ocean-atmospheric coupling
see:http://www.geo.arizona.edu/geo4xx/geos412/OcSci07.PhysProps.pdf

Comment: I, like, all Hawaiians have the ability to speak for ourselves without the help of West Pac. Furthermore, I am happy to share all of negative emails I receive on a daily basis from proponents of expansion.  I am from Kauai & I am shocked that people actually believe that Hawaiians on Kauai are so stupid that we would be manipulated by anyone concerning such an important issue.  When I attended a meeting a few months ago at our local library, proponents asked us to weigh in on the issue of whether OHA should be elevated to co-trustee of the monument or not.  I did so & concluded that OHA should be a co-trustee & co-trusteeship should be extended before expansion.  I concluded this after doing a review of literature, considered the current geo-political situation, & the impact that expansion would have on native rights & natural resources. Please give us more credit than this. Aloha Aina, Kapu Aloha, & other Waiwai Hawaii can be exercised by people from both sides of this issue.

Comment: The big ISPs will not be seen in Alaska anytime soon. But if I call someone a nincompoop for tricking my country into a war, is that civil?  How do I criticize dangerous behavior without going too far? Comment: Hi JadedJade. I also wanted to comment on the fact that the PERS pension needed to change because it wasn't sustainable in the long run. That's why it was changed beginning in 2003. The old PERS accounts were frozen and all new contributions went into OPSRP, the Oregon Public Service Retirement Plan pension. Depending on when you were hired, you were put into PERS tier 1 & 2 and OPSRP. As of Jan 1st, 2004 and going forward, all member contributions were put into their IAP, Individual Account Program in the OPSRP pension, which is basically a 401k, just like most employed Oregonians can get.  There are many factors that have contributed to the UAL (Unfunded Actuarial Liabilities). PERS members participating in variable investments during a robust market in the 1990's and early 2000's, the employer matching funds couldn't participate in those higher risk investments, huge baby boomer retirement and great recession. PERS was suppose to be 40-50% of last 3 years of average salary, not 100.

Comment: I agree with some commenters of this article.  It seems highly inappropriate of ADN to report such a story, leaving the greater Girdwoord area "vulnerable".  But such is the news. However, if the residents of Girdwood organize, and are vigilant (not vigilante) during the 2 week period, they can police the area themselves.  It might bring a few ideas to mind how to manage their police services coming from Whittier.  The next point I'd like to make is that it is foreseeable during this period that an incident involving death or injury could occur, because of troopers and their "non-response".  The liability case(s) would go on for years in the courts; the expense and settlement(s) could be in the millions [as they usually are, to avoid publicizing details.]  It seems to me it would be cheaper for the troopers to just suck it up and agree to cover Girdwood for the two week interim.  It seems foolhardy that they would just walk away.

Comment: On Memorial Day I visited the grave site of my G-G-Grandfather,  SGT Thomas Bragg, F Troop, 8th Tennessee Cavalry in Knoxville's Military Cemetery where he is buried after dying in January 1864. He died less than 100 miles from his home in Sullivan County, Tennessee.

Comment: Let's be clear about one thing - the descent into incivility in our political discourse was initiated and has been sustained by the right, not the left, and this has been especially true since President Obama was elected. When Joe Wilson shouted "You lie!" during the president's first SOTU address incivility entered the halls of what had hitherto been a civilized event. When the Senate decided to filibuster every last Democratic initiative and refused to hold hearings on a moderate Supreme Court justice appointment incivility entered those hallowed halls. Comment: The alternative is to spend wisely on maintaining infrastructure, and growing it to meet the needs.

We've tried to disregard roads and spend on light rail, streetcars and bicycle lanes and paths, and it hasn't done much.  Most of the increase in cycling has come at the expense of inner-city TriMet bus use.  MAX is basically a parking-lot shuttle for downtown government workers, Blazers and Timbers fans, but the entire region is having to pay for that system that serves just 1-2% of the total trips taken in our region, and largely by people who can afford to pay more than 25% of the operating costs of it.

Anti-road critics often criticize road users for not paying their fair share and for congestion, while allowing mass transit to cover even fewer of its costs and justifying empty trains (i.e. WES) while doing nothing about overcrowded buses (because "nobody rides the bus").  Meanwhile, cyclists want more money spent on them...but refuse to accept a tax.

Comment: This is basically true, but there are large differences both in volume and nature. It is likely true that Chinese government hackers have compromised every large western corporation. In 2010, when Google went public about its own problems in this regard (what they dubbed 'Operation Aurora'), every competent IT security department lead was nodding his or her head because it matched what they had themselves seen.  Most companies keep these breaches secret unless personal customer data is specifically stolen.

There isn't equivalence. I agree it is concerning that CSE has appeared to be hitting friendly nations for economic reasons (noteworthy: the targets were government, not private), but whatever the reason, the intel is not finding its way to corporate leaders as it does in China. The fact that we can only speculate about CSE's purposes is because that kind of information is locked down so tight.

Comment: "...who is an atheist, than would younger, less conservative...."

Not necessarily. There are lots of conservative young people on campuses today and elsewhere. And according to Pew, many unaffiliated young people turn conservative when older. "Younger" is not synonymous with "more open."

"...between Christianity and 2 party...."

In the US, the candidate with the most votes is winner of the Congressional seat. The losing party or parties win no representation at all. The unique unity of the Amer. people and the homogeneity of Christianity mitigate against large dissenting groups. But as Christianity shrinks (70% of the population now) and the unaffiliated rise, it is possible that large dissenting groups (say, of conservative Christians [both Protestant and Catholic] or of the unaffiliated) could surface.  So far, however, our two party system has been able to absorb all groups, all religious and non-religious persuasions. This is not the case in Canada, most of Western Europe, etc

Comment: In my own experience (wrapped a car around a telephone pole, broke 6 ribs, over a week in a hospital) my car insurance covered the whole thing. If your policy doesn't, then you either chose lesser coverage or you need a new insurance company. Both choices, by the way, are not afforded to people under O'care or conventional health insurance laws. Oh, you can increase your deductible in some cases, or change companies during open enrollment, or play that bizarre "gold-silver-bronze plans" game, but the fact is you can't not be covered for all the O'care mandated coverages nor can you pick a company anywhere in the country that might be cheaper. Just a couple things that make auto and health insurance very different.

Comment: Thanks for the article. I'd have liked to have seen some opinion from the middle or working classes. As Denver's popularity is undoubtedly a plus for developers and landlords of luxury buildings, what's the impact on the diversity of the city? My parents grew up in NYC when all kinds of people could afford to live there -- younger and older, working, middle, and wealthier classes. What is the prognosis for Denver as a city, in the largest sense, once it is priced out of reach of most people? And what is the impact on the poorest and homeless? What tools do other cities use to control this? (NYC had rent control that kept the city affordable. Is that even an option for Denver?) While a source quoted here say we should feel lucky, it raises the question which "we" that is. In other words, various populations are affected by the housing boom, so I'd appreciate the author to please keep them in mind the next time she writes about this issue. Thank you.

Comment: Indeed, during Harper's tenure as PM the debt financing costs dropped from 2.5% of GDP down to 1.3% of GDP, a change that saved roughly $23B in 2015.  The GST cut, by comparison, only cost about $12B/year in 2015.

A bigger change though was the decline in personal income taxes that occurred under Harper, amounting to closer about $19B/year.  These included raising the basic personal exemption, raising the tax bracket starting points, re-instating full indexing, cutting EI tax rates and the introduction of some credits.

There were also cuts to corporate taxes, but those only added to amount to about $5B/year.

The tax cuts added up to about $36B while debt financing declined by about $23B and spending, while shuffled slightly, was largely unchanged.  That is how we went from a $13B surplus in 2005/06 to a roughly balanced (no surplus or deficit) budget when Harper left office 10 years later.

Comment: I object to the high numbers of legal immigrants we allow on economic and socio-cultural grounds. I oppose illegal ("irregular"???) migrants for those reasons, plus respect for our laws.

It doesn't matter where immigrants are from or the colour of their skin or the skills they bring or don't -- too many people coming in skews the labour market in favour of buyers and against sellers. Too many newcomers without a stake in the evolution of our social contract hinder the ability of citizens to conduct the socio-political discourse of progress. Too much influx places excessive load on amenities and services that existing citizens have invested in and planned around. 

Immigration policy needs to be opened to full consideration in open and honest discourse and the decision we make must be enforced.

Comment: Normally I like Dou Saunders' columns but calling people priggish because they want to have a back yard is absurd. I spent a few years in apartments and I was heartily sick of having no yard, having to drag bags of groceries upstairs in the elevator and having nowhere to go but a narrow and unappealing balcony that was too small for a table and chairs! It's not for everybody although I accept that some folk love the freedom or have no choice. Canada is the second largest country in the world and there is no reason to be ripping up farmlands to build suburbs. If people want to live downtown then unless they have a pile of money, they're going to be stuck with high-rises but what are we going to do, bulldoze all houses and fill the lots with apartment buildings?! A better solution is what has already started to happen, a trend to smaller houses since many people live in houses far bigger than their needs would dictate.

Comment: Thank you Tegan for reporting all perspectives in this story. I respect that lodge and business owners are concerned for their livelihoods with the race reroute, but saying that a reroute diminishes the toughness of the race or the grit of the mushers is absurd. Running the Alaska Range portion of the Iditarod Trail on a dogsled with a big team is truly life-threatening without enough snow. I am a finisher of both the Iditarod and the Yukon Quest and have been a backcountry ranger in rugged Interior Alaska for 8 years. I live in a homestead without running water or road access for a good portion of the year. I'm not a lifelong Alaskan, but I am tough. Having seen my life flash before my eyes in the Burn, I feel qualified to say that mushers and dogs should not risk their lives to save someone's expensive vacation experience. I don't see the names Perrins, Gallwas or Herman in the list of Iditarod finishers.

Comment: Since WWII the world has operated on pretty surprisingly consistent 9 to 10 year economic cycles, from one recession to the next.  The last recession started in Q4 of 2008 so it is not unreasonable to guess that the NEXT recession is likely to start sometime between late 2017 and early 2019.

Why is this important?  Because the article notes that the ECB is *STILL* running in stimulus mode, even if they are trimming it back a hair.  In fact all the major central banks around the world are working in full-on stimulus mode throughout this entire economic cycle.

So what are they going to do when the NEXT recession hits?  We've already fired all our monetary and fiscal stimulus bullets.

Comment: I'm no theologian, but I am a Catholic who was fortunate enough to have had at least some of the pre-Vat-II teaching instead of the Protestant worldly "teaching" that tries to eliminate God and Heaven from Jesus.

My non-theologian interpretation of the story in which Jesus was being criticized for being annointed with expensive perfume is that Jesus was saying that He - God - was where we should be focused.

Jesus wasn't out drumming up money to make the world a better place; he was saying to let God take care of things, and even showed us by performing miracles and spending his ministry as a wanderer.  This isn't new, radical thinking on my part: ancient churches are filled with depictions of heavenly Jesuses.   

Personally, I think that once we start focusing on God, the secular stuff takes care of itself:  rather than being forced to good deeds by worldly humanists and government redistribution, we perform good deeds because of our embracing of God.

Comment: Larry, in 2012 the federal government spent $1.7 BILLION on endangered species.  That was more than the feds spent in 2011, which was more than the feds spent in 2010.  In other words, funding for endangered species is increasing.  Endangered species can't be hunted, so federal excise taxes (PR funding) doesn't even come close to the amount of federal money spent on wildlife conservation.

http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/extinction-countdown/how-much-did-the-us-spend-on-the-endangered-species-act-in-2012/

And your argument that hunters also pay income taxes is a red herring.  Yes, it's likely that the average hunter pays more for wildlife conservation than the average non-hunter, because hunters pay the federal excise tax as well as for hunting licenses and tags.  However, hunters comprise less than 10% of Americans.  So non-hunters, as a group, pay far more than hunters in income tax, some of which is spent on managing wildlife in refuges, parks and other federal lands.

Comment: Perhaps the author would have preferred if the Spanish or Portuguese had settled North America... 
The suggestion that pre-settlement North America was some harmonious society is rooted in unapologetic contempt for reality. North America is never going to go backwards - Canada didn't become one of the most advanced and richest societies in the world by accident. Our infrastructure: schools, hospitals, roads, environmental stewardship - are all a function of progress and value creation stemming from European settlement.  The idea of pre-settlement utopias have no basis in historical fact: life was hard, violent, and short prior to Europeans arriving in North America. 
I am Canadian and I am tired of being demonized as a colonizer who's existence and livelihood represents "cultural genocide" as if I am actively oppressing First Nations. I'm not going to apologize for anything, I respect people regardless of race, religion, gender, or sexual orientation. Sorry not sorry.

Comment: It takes the US Forest Service, discovering by accident, one of the many environmental toxic contaminant threats currently polluting this state of Oregon, solely because the state (and federal) public health and wildlife protection agencies cannot do their mandated responsibilities for detection, assessment, and public protection because legislatures are being irresponsible. The legislature sets the tone by funding, or withholding funding, of agency effort to effectively do their mandated work. For very many years, a culture has built up for the 'avoidance at any cost' of toxic contaminant monitoring unless some crisis in the media pushed a stop-gap blatant need. Agencies fear punitive legislative reductions of any agency that 'makes waves' by pointedly investigative work that could demonstrate ongoing toxic pollution for humans and wildlife. Legislatures erroneously see such investigatory monitoring as being inherently politically and fiscally subversive, but such work is essential.

Comment: All republics with a parliamentary system have a head of state usually called a "President" ---though the office could be called "governor" or "governor-general" or "king" or "big cheese" or whatever---and a head of government usually called a "Prime Minister" -- in Germany the title is "Chancellor".  If you think about it for a while, you'll realize why it is important to have a head of state distinct from the head of government in a parliamentary system.  The US is unusual in having a head of state but no head of government whose position is dependent on the ability to command support from a legislative assembly.

Comment: In the West and in China and Japan, "we" have an effective way to reduce population, whether "excess" or not, and geographers call it "the demographic shift" which amounts to smaller families on average, smaller than the "replacement level" or a little above 2 children per woman. The shift requires societies to have health care adequate to reduce infant and child mortality, as well as universal education, especially for women, and adequate food. The downside is an oversupply of the elderly, causing economic problems. We and other nations use immigration in part to pay for the upkeep of the old; but in our case we are running out of immigrants as our neighbor nations enter demographic shift, but we can import plenty of willing workers from the Middle East, most of which hasn't entered the demographic shift. A rising population generally accompanies an expanding economy.

I would think that as a Christian nation we would take care of the sick and the poor, as Jesus did. So what happened?

US Constitution  Article I, section 10, clause 1.  :

"No State shall ....pass any ....Law impairing the Obligation of Contracts, " 

Oregon Constitution:  Article I, Section 21

 "Section 21. Ex-post facto laws; laws impairing contracts; laws depending on authorization in order to take effect; laws submitted to electors.

Comment: As an agnostic, those concepts do not define existence as part of this society for me.   The science of zygotes and their becoming 'human beings' however any society defines a 'human being',  is independent of that particular belief system for me.   There are and have been millions of people who view their existence through that set of prisms.  There are and have been millions more who view their existence differently.  Those with faith in a deity or even in the particular one described in the Bible may be right; those without that faith or any other faith may also be right.  That is why I am an agnostic and not an atheist.  The existence or non-existence of a deity is a matter of unprovable belief for me.  Faith, religion and theology are interesting concepts; they don't define my perceptions of reality.

Comment: If you're the one guy outside of Amazon who knows WHY Amazon is building a 2nd HQ outside Seattle, do please let us know.  Without knowing WHY they are doing it, you are unlikely to know that they've already excluded Denver as a candidate. I agree 100% it could be a show to create a two-horse race with a predetermined winner, but that predetermined winner could well be Denver.  One theory on the driver is that Amazon doesn't want its sole HQ to be located on a major fault line for earthquakes.  If you're looking to avoid war, natural disaster, climate change effects, create a central hub in your largest market, and locate in a place attractive to your workforce, you won't find a better spot than Denver.  Given that, and the fact that Tabor is putting huge economic strains on state and local funding, I'd say "please come, but we expect you to be a good corporate citizen from Day 1, and that includes paying (most all) your taxes."  Denver will succeed this century with or without Amazon.

Because when you go to arbitration the last question you want to be asked is this entry contemporaneous. There are only two conditions to refuse an order, it is illegal, or it is unsafe. What you view as nit picking is a daily occurrence for both supervisor and shop stewards, to the point that I have had supervisors sign my entry and add their own explanation. So we have a different point of view, I am a worker and you have a management perspective, please correct if I am wrong. You will notice that I have ignored most of the entries, as you say they are nit picking, and I have paid attention to one entry that if it did happen, would be a bad thing. What I read in your writing, correct if I am wrong, you think it didn't happen or is an exaggeration. Why not find out?

Comment: A major reason to buy and support local products.  Hard to imagine why we would buy "questionable quality" imported fish or seafood products, when we are surrounded by an ocean of fresh fish and seafood products that are 2nd to none.  I realize it all boils down to saving money by importing cheaper quality products, but maybe we need to find ways to make things more profitable for our local food businesses and producers so they can be more competitive with foreign imports.  Importing 2nd rate quality of seafood makes no sense if people will get sick.
